content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												If you want a way to blow a few bucks on a game that's less than 2 hours long this is pretty good. The game ends way too quickly and the concepts introduced are barely compounded upon in the late game. There is little story and just when it feels like the game is going to take off and start getting serious... it' over. It feels like an hour long tutorial to a more complicated game. The music isn't that great at all and it isn't really an "artistic" game either. It's a neat idea but there isn't any meat to this game at all. It feels like this game was thrown together real quick to make a quick buck.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												Pros:-Metroidvania with matching art style-Interesting teleporting mechanics with different beams that do different things-Starts difficult, which makes it reminiscent of older games and their difficulty-60FPS?-Good soundtrackCons:-Pits of death. EVERYWHERE. And they're so open that it's hard not to fall in them during a puzzle.-Vertical Platforming that, if you fail one part, you will fall down a screen back to nearly the beginning every time.-Actually, all the puzzles make you restart them in one way or another when you fail one part.-Soundtrack doesn't really match up with the mood of some situations-NPCs are borderline useless to talk to, despite you being consistently encouraged to talk to them-WAY too many tutorials. Every time you see a new beam, the game wants you to know what it is. Every time a pixel on a graphic is shaded differently, the game has to bring up a slow-moving dialogue box to tell you. LET ME FIGURE IT OUT.-Puzzle mechanics are interesting, but they get bland very quickly, so to remedy that something new appears every screen or so in the beginning. This, however, will make the game even more bland in the end because there's way too much involved into the game that it's too complicated and ends up being uninteresting anyways.-Every once in a while I get lag spikes for some reason. I'm running on an Intel i7-4500U with 8GB RAM on Windows 10 (Home Edition) 64-bit. There is absolutely no reason this game should have any lag spikes. Also why does it claim it requires 512MB VRAM on the store page? Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 Full Burst and Revolution require the same specs and is more graphically demanding in every way I can think of than this game. Also 1GB of RAM does seem like a lot to ask for with this sort of game Possibly unoptimized engine or code? I mean, I'm sure it can run on most machines decently, but if the developers here were working for a publisher for a larger-scale game, it would be unacceptable if they were to make the game require way more resources from the computer than it really should.Conclusion:Not really worth $1.99, you'd be better off paying around half of that for the game, or less.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Out There Somewhere claims to have been inspired by Cave Story and Super Metroid, but those games raise expectations in my mind that I feel the game did not meet. The game is far shorter than expected, my first playthrough lasting little more than an hour. It is also not nearly as varied as Cave Story and other Metroidvania-style games; you will spend the majority of the game with just your teleport gun and a normal gun. And while the puzzles involving the aforementioned teleport gun are definitely interesting, the claimed inspiritations led me to believe I would have a bigger arsenal at my disposal.Another issue I have with the game is the use of bullet hell-like portions of the game. These sections feel very out of place in a game that is otherwise essentially a 2D version of Portal.Out There Somewhere is a decent game, considering the price, but the tauted inspirations to me implied a set of standards that the game did not deliver. Like I said above, this is 2D Portal. If that is what you want, then this game will do. But if you're looking for something Metroidvania-esque, look elsewhere.

3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												This review is based on the first few levels, but already I'm impressed by the music and the 2D portal mechanics, which utilizes your teleport gun.The story consists of Captain Yuri, a generic anime space cop chasing a generic fugitive alien warlord (named Grigori for whatever odd reason) onto the surface of the planet that they have botch crash landed on. Noticed the typo did you? Yeah there are a few in the game as well. I'm going to get to why I changed my review from a positive to a negative by the end of the game, but first we have to look at the positives:Pros:Silly fun and cool acheivementsOutstanding music, seriously it's never annoyingClever easter eggs and referencesFun "2D Portal" platforming, yes there are a lot of portal copycats, but this one is done wellSounds great, right? How could I not like this game after saying all these nice things about it? Well here we go:Cons:The plot is recycled barf, not that I expected much from this type of game, however this particular execution of "You're the hero, he's the villian, go duke it out somewhere... IN SPACE" was tired at best, which doesn't lend itself to the story like a Metroid game, or hell, even Portal's story was better. "We're here to do research on portals, oh just kidding, I'm a sociopathic computer that has been trying to kill you this entire time!"This ultimately results in the one and only boss battle in the entire game. Did I mention this game was short? Yeah so with such a great game so far, guess what they went with for the boss battle, the one and only boss battle? How did JonTron put it again?Oh yes.Simon ♥♥♥♥ING says.Grigori goes from the left wall to the right every three times you hit him, and the only gun you have in the game you get in the second act (this game is not long enough to even have a third, mind you) and it's not a bazooka, it's a tiny little pea shooter that kills normal enemies in 4 hits, and Gregori needs half a bazillion to go down.Then Grigori decides it's time for round two in some spaceships that you've both miraculously had time to repair, and get this - during the game you were supposed to have picked up power ups you can only use in this one battle, but they are barely explained to you, and I don't think I picked up more than one. Oh what to do... Can't go back for them, so onwards you go for some more....SIMON ♥♥♥♥ING SAYS... BULLET HELL MODE.Yes, I ragequit that boss, yes, speedrunners have beaten this game in a clean 17 minutes...Maybe I'll go back and kill the dumb boss later...No, don't get it unless it's on sale, if for nothing else but the music, or just buy the soundtrack if it's available.Final verdict:3/10 - Cool (OK borrowed) concept and music with nice pixel visuals, but it all goes down the drain due to a tedious and unforgiving boss fight, and the lack of content or emotional investment/story development overall.

number of helpful: 9 of 23 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												I literally beat this game in 54 minutes. When I beat the first boss (the only boss) the credits rolled and I thought the developers were making a joke. This is probably the shortest game I have ever played, and I was greatly disappointed by that. This game describes itself as taking the pages out of Super Metroid and Cave Story, both very long games with enormous worlds to explore, but this game is nothing like them at all. It's a shame, because what is in the game is awesome. Everything is built just right and it's something new I've never encountered before. But, this game is virtually a tech demo of what should have been a much more expansive game. If the developers made a sequel to this I'd buy it in a heartbeat, but this game by itself just isn't long enough to merit a purchase at its listed retail price.

content:

												This game is ok, but I have a few problems-1. The keys are so dumb. jump is z. Like what even. You can rebind them, but not to something sensible like up or space.2. The levels are repetetive. I'm already bored with the art style and level design3. The game brings nothing new. If you're looking for a retro platformer, look elsewhere. The classics are far better than this. Shovel knight did it right, but this has a lame story, dull characters, and nonexistanct plot.4. Did I mention that the levels are repetative?5. I beat the game in under an hour. I'm no speedrunner either. It's certainly not worth $5. You'd be better off playing some flash games.The soundtrack is pretty good though, but I mean, isn't that expected of modern retro games by now?tl;dr- Repetetive, frustrating, and terrible keybinding that you can't use up or space in. Brings nothing new to the genre.(I got this for 20 cents though so if its on sale get it then farm the cards :D

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												Out There Somewhere is a waste of time.  Everything about it is uninteresting.  The puzzles are never challenging and the teleportation mechanic is berely explored.  Most enemies can be ignored and killing them is a chore because the gun fires too slowly.  Instead of being engaging, each obstacle only serves to inconvenience you.  The colors are so same-y, all the envoronments blend together, and so dark it's sometimes unclear where enemies and platforms are.  The music is generic and the writing is boring and entirely unneccessary.  Things were only put in the game because games usually have them, not because they add anything to the experience.  All they add are a few seconds to the game's paltry length.Everything in this game has been done better in a thousand internet flash games.  Instead of spending money on this, go online and play one for free.

Posted: October 21, 2016
												The game is ridiculously difficult, even with a gamepad.Update:It turns out all i had to do was git gud. Once i figured out how to double jump, the game was a breeze. I even did a second, much quicker run of the game where i was able to get nearly all cores and artifacts, upgrade the ship, and defeat the bad guy, in 40 minutes or less.So... the game is actually pretty decent after all: cute graphics and music, and fairly interesting puzzles and secrets.By the way, the secret to double jumping is that the character must touch the floor and jump right before the teleportation. So, just time the jump to land before the pellet hits the wall, keep your eyes on it, and jump right before it hits.

Posted: September 11, 2015
												It's a really nice, little game. The pixel art is interesting through adding little effects here and there, like how the background is always moving, yet it's not distracting. It makes a cool visual. The game's setting has an oddly not-so-desolate, metroid-like, planet as a setting, which I'm also a big fan of. Another thing I enjoyed was that all the NPC's were nice little guys, and came some interesting lines, if you went the distance to talk to them. The soundtrack is also really nice, it fits the space theme without being boring. The puzzles (stages that have you use a portal gun to advance) were difficult, but never so hard that I gave up. That was a big one for me, and it probably had to do with how well you could see the puzzle in whole, and the simple mechanics. I really love the puzzles. The story is... not very exisistent. There is some bad guy, Grigori (ugly fellow), who is a total jerk, he blew up your ship, you wreck, so now you have to find him on this planet you wrecked on (I don't know why the bad guy is there, I think we were trying to go to the planet to attack him, buy it's not well explained). It does provide an objective, but it isn't very complicated. In whole, I bought the game for $0.16 (an awesome price), and was surprised. However, the game is really short. My 3 hours were all I needed to beat the game. But, if you're okay with short games, it's a lovely experience. I was only upset at the length to be honest. It feels incomplete,  like a greenlight game. I really want more cool puzzles and funny creatures, but then the games over. I also beleive that with more time it could have a neat little plot to help tie the story together. I just want more. An update with a story that goes somewhere (maybe to other planets) would solve all my issues with this game. There are collectables and an achievement for completing the game under an hour, which make the game more replayable in its defense, but it just won't fill the void.

Posted: July 1, 2015
												Very begrudgingly, I recommend this game. Very begrudgingly! I did enjoy this game. It had fun mechanics, a nice look. Some good little humor thrown in here and there, but it didn't really have too much of a drive towards it. Near the end of the game I forgot I still had a nemesis to beat... and that his name was Grigorio. I was just concentrating on getting that orb... thing. And the main bulk of the gameplay is Portal-esque 2D puzzle platforming, and it's puzzling that doesn't just require know-how, it also requires good timing and patience. This game has a big difficulty curve, and you really need to think outside the box in order to beat it. My biggest complaint would have to be... the last boss. The game only has you do the 2D sideshooter for the first minute of the game, then expects you to hop back in knowing exactly what you're doing, right when you have to kill the final bloody boss. Thank you game, I have a brain, but not as fast of an adaptable one as you may think I do. With the main push towards patience, timing, and creative thinking- Out There Somewhere pushes it right out the door with the fast-paced, shoot-em-up with the final boss, and I did not like it. At all. But for what it's worth, the main bulk of the game and its gameplay is very nice. A fine throwback to old-school Nintendo games... but with a much nicer look.

Posted: September 5, 2015
												*NOTE: This review was written by an individual who purchased the item at the time when it was  obscenely discounted (96%)!*Portal + Metroid (NES) = Out There Somewhere.  This was a great little game, and I would have loved to have seen it last longer.  It took me about 2 hours to beat the game, but there is a marginal amount of replayability if you push for acquiring all of the Steam achievements.The game is 2D Metroid (NES) style and is very linear, with a few optional detours for special items if you feel up to it.  Each side-scrolling screen you pass into plays out as increasingly difficult Portal-type, platforming puzzles.  Near the 2/3 mark of the game, there were perhaps 2 screens that were difficult enough that I had to cave in and check a walkthrough for and when I found the answer, it was a slap-upside-the-head DERP answer I felt like I should have obviously known, but some spots do require some brain-power, which were refreshing.*DISCLAIMER: Everyone and their dead dog needs to buy this game while it is only 19 cents to purchase!  That being said, although it is a ton of fun, I personally would not recommend it for the full $4.99 price tag due to the overall lack of bang for your buck.*

Posted: September 7, 2015
												This is a good example of a game that does a lot with a little. The tile art is simple, but pretty enough. Tiles don't always tile, but that's nothing worth griping about. It would've been cool to see some more artsy elements, but overall nothing detracts from play, and that's the important part.  It speaks for itself and there is never any visual confusion save for the occaisional cliff that you're certain must be surmountable.The gameplay is good. Controls do exactly what you expect them to once you get comfortable with them. The puzzles do a lot with just two tools. Because of the ease of use and the length of the game (1-2 hours if you REALLY take your time) this is one of the few titles where I'm compelled to beat it 100% with all achievements.Grab it while it's cheap and have some good, classic fun.

												*NOTE: This review was written by an individual who purchased the item at the time when it was  obscenely discounted (96%)!*Portal + Metroid (NES) = Out There Somewhere.  This was a great little game, and I would have loved to have seen it last longer.  It took me about 2 hours to beat the game, but there is a marginal amount of replayability if you push for acquiring all of the Steam achievements.The game is 2D Metroid (NES) style and is very linear, with a few optional detours for special items if you feel up to it.  Each side-scrolling screen you pass into plays out as increasingly difficult Portal-type, platforming puzzles.  Near the 2/3 mark of the game, there were perhaps 2 screens that were difficult enough that I had to cave in and check a walkthrough for and when I found the answer, it was a slap-upside-the-head DERP answer I felt like I should have obviously known, but some spots do require some brain-power, which were refreshing.*DISCLAIMER: Everyone and their dead dog needs to buy this game while it is only 19 cents to purchase!  That being said, although it is a ton of fun, I personally would not recommend it for the full $4.99 price tag due to the overall lack of bang for your buck.*

Posted: September 4, 2015
												A charming and fun (if highly derivative and overdone) stylized platformer with a retro art style and a snappy chiptune soundtrack. You may see this and think "ugh this style of game has been played literally to death" and you'd be right, but this deserves its due diligence for being a really clever little game.I feel it's very much like an alternate-universe take on VVVVVV's gameplay mechanics; instead of a gravity flip you have a simple teleportation gun, kind of like an ultra-simplified Portal; you shoot a beam that sends you in a straight line to wherever it hits, which in theory sounds pretty lame, but the level design makes for some very tricky and mind-bending puzzle situations. You'd be a fool to pass this up for 19 cents. Hell, even its full asking price of $4.99. A fun little romp for fans of the aforementioned VVVVVV and similar games.

In fact it was probably the easiest part of the game. Overall this game is great, great retro style graphics, great mechanics, great gameplay, great music, meh final boss. 9/10

Posted: July 1, 2015
												Very begrudgingly, I recommend this game. Very begrudgingly! I did enjoy this game. It had fun mechanics, a nice look. Some good little humor thrown in here and there, but it didn't really have too much of a drive towards it. Near the end of the game I forgot I still had a nemesis to beat... and that his name was Grigorio. I was just concentrating on getting that orb... thing. And the main bulk of the gameplay is Portal-esque 2D puzzle platforming, and it's puzzling that doesn't just require know-how, it also requires good timing and patience. This game has a big difficulty curve, and you really need to think outside the box in order to beat it. My biggest complaint would have to be... the last boss. The game only has you do the 2D sideshooter for the first minute of the game, then expects you to hop back in knowing exactly what you're doing, right when you have to kill the final bloody boss. Thank you game, I have a brain, but not as fast of an adaptable one as you may think I do. With the main push towards patience, timing, and creative thinking- Out There Somewhere pushes it right out the door with the fast-paced, shoot-em-up with the final boss, and I did not like it. At all. But for what it's worth, the main bulk of the game and its gameplay is very nice. A fine throwback to old-school Nintendo games... but with a much nicer look.

Posted: August 16, 2015
												I found this to be a very insteresting game. I didn't pay any attention to it at first, and got it as a part of bundle when it was on sale, and it took my brother to launch it and play a bit for me to realise that it's the exact game I'd like to play.tl;dr: I fell in love with it from the first actual sight :DGameplay here is like an old arcade, you have 5 buttons to satisfy all you needs, left/right+jump, teleport bullet and damaging bullet,It's easy to learn and pretty easy to go through, especially since game is pretty short (you can see that it can be finished under 20 minutes, took me ~15 on my first and last speed run). But if you want to uncover all the secrets that this game has you'll need to put your mind and reflexes into it. Most, if not all, secret places are spottable if you know where to look, but getting there might become the real problem there.I quite enjoyed the ride, even though it lasted only 4 hours for me to get all the achievements and find all the secrets. I still recommend it, especially if it's on sale.Overall: 10 secret gun upgrades out of 10

Posted: July 3, 2015
												The thinking man's platformer game.Yes this game is short, but it has everything you want out of the mechanics. It makes you think, and lets you have fun. When you solve a certain room/puzzle the game lets you know you did well with an achievement, which is both corny and delightful.While this game is not open like VVVVVV, it has many of the same basic charms. Every screen is like a small puzzle, and you can not get stuck where the game experience has not taught you the skills required to succeed in the later parts of the game.It looked like there could be more from this game, and I would be happy to see it. Many of the puzzles were good and never repeated quite the same way twice. The two (three?) boss fights were interesting enough.I'll probably replay the game to try for 100%, even though there was not a progress label, but I did notice I missed a few things on my first run.

Posted: July 3, 2015
												Amazing game, worth way more than 20 cents. I think the 5 dollars is a reasonable price. It's fun albeit short, and plays smoothly. You should beat it in approximately 1 and a half hours on your first playthrough, but if you try to get all the achievements you'll be playing for a lot longer. Developers: make a sequel. I really enjoy this style, especially since the actual Metroid series isn't doing so great at the moment, this made me feel a bit of that feeling again, of exploration, adventure and space.The platforming is certainly different, but reminds me a bit of shinesparking, especially the really difficult sections.I personally haven't played cave story so I can't compare it to that, and I feel like the only thing really taken from portal was the teleport gun, so as far as I'm concerned, if you like metroid then certainly get this game. This games only downfall was its length, and I would happily play more like this. One of the best aspects they used from Metroid was sequence breaking. This is when you speed run and find ways to skip certain sections of the game (kinda neat how one of the achievements is exactly this, Shortcut) or have an item earlier in the game than you are supposed to (Daredevil). Finding out these things on your own, is what makes this game like metroid.One let down I felt was the text. Now I understand how complicated the portal gun is, and that the text is mostly necessary, but I felt that I didn't connect to the maini character as well. Super Metroid is a classic example of a game that needs almost no text, in fact the only text is at the beginning to explain what happened in the previous two games. But this is only a minor complaint, and a tip for the Devs if you are planning to make a sequel.Nonetheless, this game is very enjoyable, and I'd just like to say thank you for helping me connect with Metroid again. To everyone else, I highly recommend this game, especially for the price it is right now.

Posted: April 29, 2015
												This is a mix between Portal and Super Metroid.  The controls are tight and the gameplay is original.  Using the portal gun in this game really makes you rethink standard platforming conventions, and when you get the hang of the controls the game is a lot of fun.  I got this game on sale for 19 cents and it was certainly worth more than that.  However, I beat the campaign with many secrets in under an hour, so I'm not sure it is worth the full 5 dollar asking price.  Replayability is in trying to unlock all the secrets, although even unlocking them all during a second playthrough only adds another 30-60 min of gameplay.  In all, this is a really interesting game and I'd certainly recommend it during a sale.

Posted: April 25, 2015
												SPOILERS BELOWThis is a pretty good game.  It's solid most of the way through.  There is one downside though: The final battle.  While most of the game focuses on puzzle platforming, the very final battle (at least I think it's the final battle) takes all the concepts of your adventure, and it...  Throws them in the trash.  While the first Grigori battle actually focused on your abilities with the teleport gun, the final battle doesn't.  It puts you in a little space battle of Grigori's ship vs. your ship.  No teleport gun, just blasters.  What makes the final battle even more terrible is that the boss seems to have every cheap attack available: Spread shot, homing missiles, and a beam that takes up a large portion of the screen.  It's even more frustrating when they are all used at once.  This battle is the only reason I haven't finished the game.  Is this a cheap review?  Yes.  Do I reccomend the game?  Overall, yes.  Do I recommend completing/beating the game?  No, I don't.

Posted: June 30, 2015
												Im not to big on platformer puzzle games. But I really love this game. The concept of a teleport gun gave the level design alot of potential, and the developers definitely took advantage of most of this potential. Although some puzzles in the game could be completely by passed by either time a jump just right or soaring across a good chunck of the map by leaping off of a giant beacon tower thing, most of them were really engaging. Some of them really made me stop and think and plan things out. And most of the levels not only required you to think about the puzzle, but also made you react while performing this level. This concept isnt new, but it is in the game and really complements the gameplay. Being such a short game as well, the ending boss battle comes very quickly. The entire game took me 50 minutes for me to complete on my first attempt, but the boss battle was insane. A good kind of insane. And although very difficult in my opinion, it was definitely one of the most enjoyable boss battles I have encountered.     I got the game on sale for 19 cents, but the game is definitley worth its full $5. I would have loved to pay the full $5 dollars to support the developers and get some more content! But it is for sure worth your money.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												Would definitely recommend, but once again with many games on Steam it's only worth buying when it is at 20 cents. About 1.5 hours on first playthrough and thus the only thought going through my head was that it was equivalent to a really well made flash game online. Now that we're past that...Pros:Great opening, captured the retro feel in both the cutscene and sidescroll space shooter part, especially the forced death trope was done nicely. Gameplay is smooth, fun, and rewarding. It definitely takes inspiration from VVVVV though, but no problem there. Sound is amazing, the soundtrack is great for a 20 cent game. Also a nice bit of collectibles that are well hidden, so it is good for speedruns too.Cons:A bit short so once again buy it on the cheap. The idea of the teleport gun is somewhat cliche and some parts (such as the first part of the final boss fight) felt like a lame flash game made by some 12 year old, in which the boss has only 2 moves and both are really easy to avoid. Overall this game is mostly fun aside from a few "eh" moments, so buy it on sale.

Posted: September 10, 2015
												A nice little platformer game that combines a Portal-like idea with 2D platforming genre. It took me 2 and a half hours to beat it, though there are achievements to beat it under an hour and to beat it under 20 minutes. That may sound short, and I have no idea how one is supposed to beat this game under 20 minutes, but for what this game is, it could have been bad if it lasted longer. Overall, this game is good and quite fun.Side note: There are two 2D space shooting segments, one at the beginning of the game and one as a second (last) phase of the final boss fight. Keep in mind that this game *is* a 2D platforming game, so don't get confused, angry, discouraged or something else like that when you find yourself in space. It's okay.

Posted: September 9, 2015
												Out There Somewhere is a laid back puzzle platformer. The main mechanic is a teleportation gun which allows you to teleport where you shoot. The gun is similar to the one in The Swapper but time doesn't slow down when you fire it and you can't make multiple copies. The difference is that this teleportation gun preserves momentum. So if you fire it at a wall and jump right before the projectile hits you'll be jumping when you teleport.This leads to some interesting gameplay the first time through and some very interesting exploring on the second playthrough. The game clocks in at about 2-3 hours for the first playthough but it's almost better the second time through when you're better with the mechanics. It has a couple shmup sections but they are brief, which is bad if you're a shmup fan but good if you suck at them like I do.Overall I really enjoyed this game. If you like puzzle platformers with interesting mechanics I'd definitely recommend this to you.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												There is absolutely no reason not to play this game. Its REALLY fun!Pros :-Clever switch between space shooter and platformer. Not many indies do this.-Mindbending teleportation platforming. Reminiscent of Portal, esp. in that you keep your momentum.-Really cute an colorful pixel art, esp. the character portraits. Reminiscent of Cave Story.-Fun platforming in general-Some secrets add some more game time, like in Metroid.-Really reasonable price (21c on summer sale)-Difficulty is just right... could of gone further and more challenging though.Cons :-Space shooter is very primitive and short. A short portion at the beginning and after the final boss.-Game is pretty short (I beat it in literally an hour)-Some music, while cute, has very short loops that get annoying when you die a lot.-Combat is non-existant at first, and even after a gun is acquired enemies can easily be avoided in most cases.-Only one boss fight, which is rather simple-Unsatisfying ending-Practically non-existant story. There is some dialogue and pixel-art cutscenes, but that's it. Don't expect to meet interesting characters like in Cave Story.In conclusion : really fun, short and sweet little pixel-art platformer that will appeal to anyone that likes platformers. Its short but its cheap, so its worth it.8/10

Posted: May 7, 2016
												I purchased this game during a recent sale and paid about 49 cents for it. The game is most definitely worth that price, but I cannot say it is worth the full 2 dollars.  The Good:1. I always have a soft spot for the pixelated, nostaligic graphics and sounds. 2. The sound track is amazing and does tend to be stuck in ones head after you sit down the controller. 3. The physics and animations were well done, basically perfect. 4. I did like the merger of the side scrollinger shooter and the planetary exploration/platforming. I found them to be very   complimentary to one another in this game.5.  Personally, I liked having to avoid the enemies, relying heavily on the telportation gun. I liked the puzzle aspect oft his game, though it was a bit easy. The bad:1. The game was too short. My first play through, and not in any particular rush to beat the game, took 40 minutes.  this is taking into consideration the time I spent trying to get some of the extra items. 2. The developers said this game was directly inspired by Cave Story and Super Metroid, but I fail to see much of those characteristics in this game. It is possible that I am not looking or thinking hard enough. I expected more weopons, different abilities that would allow you to progress, etc.  This game did not feel as atmospheric or epic as metroid and was not long enough to qualify for any kind of story, like Cave Story. 3. The puzzle aspect of this game, while I love it, is wayyyyy too simple. Once you get the hang of the fact that the teleporation gun conserves momentum, you have beaten the game.  4. Not a whole lot of variety. I disagree with the main character when he says that 3 types of beam obstacles are too many. They are not enough. 5. One could argue that this is trying to turn the game into something its not, but: I wanted to see more than one planet. I wanted more intermmediate shooter levels and more planets to explore. I'm not suggesting a re-write, but the simple addition of more content that is already within the bounds of the game engine.  "I'm sorry, but Grigori is on another planet" would have been an accpetable transition between levels. Overall:The game felt less than half completed, like a teaser trailer of itself. Imagine the first mario brothers game, on the NES, if the princess was really in the first castle. That is this game. I think this game could be great if it just expanded on the content a bit. I am not suggesting anything revolutionary. A few more obstacles and perhaps some variety to the planet (or add more than one planet).  Achievements do not do it for me and did not add to the game.  For < 1 dollar, this game can be recommended. Not for the full price.

Posted: August 14, 2015
												This game can be pretty enjoyable for a few hours, and it's somewhat memorable. I'll go over its notable aspects here.StoryThe story is pretty much as basic as it can get, cliché even. However, I was satisfied with how they handled it in implementation. Whoever designed the story segments was well aware that nobody would care. Instead of shoving some bland exposition down your throat while you slump lifelessly over your keyboard and wonder if playing through this game is a commitment you're willing to make, it provides the story in short, quickly skippable (or quickly readable) lines of text. You can get through it in a few seconds, and you're not missing much if you ignore it entirely. The gist is that you're a spaceman on a foreign planet and need to kill some guy. Narrative gold.GraphicsThe pixel art isn't bad. It's not anything special. It's not too repetitive. Sprites gel pretty well with each other, but tile sprites stick strictly to their square shape and corners aren't adorned in any way to reduce the jaggedness of such defined tiles. All of the main character's animations are so beautifully fluid, though, and the walking animation is adorable.AudioThe music is pretty average. Sometimes it gets better, but it gets redundant and loses its charm as it loops. In the game's store page description, it throws around names such as Cave Story. If they're going to tote around a reference to a game like that, I think it's only fair to interpret that as a standard to hold their game to. It falls abysmically below this standard.ControlsControls feel fine and function as intended. Some precision is required, but it's not unforgiving.MechanicsThis is the good bit. The game is based on traversing through puzzles using a simple mechanic: You can fire projectiles horizontally. When these projectiles impact something, you are teleported to the point of impact. Combine this with precision platforming and quick thinking, and you can pull off some neat stunts. New objects are introduced that add more depth to the puzzles. For example, there are colored beams that can destroy, obstruct, or even redirect your shots. These can be toggled by switches or obstructed by objects. I think the store page description's comparison of this game to Portal is actually pretty fair. While the mechanics and dimensionality are different, they require the same kind of problem solving and reflex. The teleportation gun is ineffective as a weapon, however, which brings us to...CombatAt first, you have to avoid enemies entirely because you lack a means of removing them. At some point, your character aquires a new tool: a firearm. Now, the first thing you'd want to do is go out and start packing heat at anything that looks like it could accommodate a few bullets, but you'd soon find out that your shiny new baby isn't very empowering. There are only a few types of enemies. Some exist to serve as barriers in the puzzles, and your weapon is only a tool for removing them. The rest exist just so that there are enemies. They're usually not challenging or unique, but I suppose they do add some variance. You can collect hidden items to increase the number of hits you can take, but health isn't really something that needs to be managed. Other than the boss battle, the combat isn't explored past this.I'd like to point out that the store page description also points to Super Metroid, and again interpret such a reference as justification to compare these games both ways. Again, it's not even a close comparison.At the end, you have to utilize both your teleport gun and firearm to battle the main antagonist by moving around the room to dodge attacks and position yourself to have a clear shot. This part is actually quite well done, but I was not at all prepared for what came next. That's covered in...Level Design and ProgressionPuzzles can be pretty creative. They're typically not too difficult, and checkpoints are generous enough to ensure that you're not getting frustrated about replaying the same sections. Puzzles frequently introduce new ways to utilize the tools that you already have, rarely feeling repetitive. If you're observant and think a little more to get to alternate paths, you can get rewarded with items, even if they're not always useful. The puzzles are overall satisfying and engaging.The largest and ugliest flaw of this game is its length. When I reached the end, I was unsure if I was just misinterpreting what was going on. It was just so absurdly short. It was a decent ride, though.Now, I'd like to explain how it pulls off this ending. In the last section, I mentioned a boss battle in which you use what you've gained to take out the main antagonist. After he's defeated, you get out of there, walk a screen or two, and then it slams into you so unnervingly hard. Suddenly, the quite enjoyable puzzle platformer I was playing now has me careening through space in my ship, toe to toe with another.I am now suddenly playing a side-scrolling shoot 'em up sequence. There is no similar puzzle mechanic or anything. There's just dodging and mashing to spam bullets. I personally do not enjoy shmups. I barely play them, and when I do, they do not entertain me. I didn't know that I was in for this when I played through a puzzle-oriented "action platformer," as the store page describes it.Anyway, maybe I just suck at these things, but I didn't have the motivation to power through that final boss battle. I got someone else to help me out with the mashing part, just for the sake of completion.RatingI've decided to rate this game positively for two reasons: I picked it up on sale for a nice price, and the majority of the game's mechanics and level design were pleasant and impressive.TL;DRI originally intended for this to be brief, but yet again, I rambled far too long. Basically, the only good selling point is the great puzzle-based gameplay. The game is incredibly short (a few hours at best), so it's best to pick it up on sale. I wouldn't advise paying for it at full price unless you're an afficionado for this stuff.

Posted: September 11, 2015
												It's a really nice, little game. The pixel art is interesting through adding little effects here and there, like how the background is always moving, yet it's not distracting. It makes a cool visual. The game's setting has an oddly not-so-desolate, metroid-like, planet as a setting, which I'm also a big fan of. Another thing I enjoyed was that all the NPC's were nice little guys, and came some interesting lines, if you went the distance to talk to them. The soundtrack is also really nice, it fits the space theme without being boring. The puzzles (stages that have you use a portal gun to advance) were difficult, but never so hard that I gave up. That was a big one for me, and it probably had to do with how well you could see the puzzle in whole, and the simple mechanics. I really love the puzzles. The story is... not very exisistent. There is some bad guy, Grigori (ugly fellow), who is a total jerk, he blew up your ship, you wreck, so now you have to find him on this planet you wrecked on (I don't know why the bad guy is there, I think we were trying to go to the planet to attack him, buy it's not well explained). It does provide an objective, but it isn't very complicated. In whole, I bought the game for $0.16 (an awesome price), and was surprised. However, the game is really short. My 3 hours were all I needed to beat the game. But, if you're okay with short games, it's a lovely experience. I was only upset at the length to be honest. It feels incomplete,  like a greenlight game. I really want more cool puzzles and funny creatures, but then the games over. I also beleive that with more time it could have a neat little plot to help tie the story together. I just want more. An update with a story that goes somewhere (maybe to other planets) would solve all my issues with this game. There are collectables and an achievement for completing the game under an hour, which make the game more replayable in its defense, but it just won't fill the void.

Posted: September 10, 2015
												A nice little platformer game that combines a Portal-like idea with 2D platforming genre. It took me 2 and a half hours to beat it, though there are achievements to beat it under an hour and to beat it under 20 minutes. That may sound short, and I have no idea how one is supposed to beat this game under 20 minutes, but for what this game is, it could have been bad if it lasted longer. Overall, this game is good and quite fun.Side note: There are two 2D space shooting segments, one at the beginning of the game and one as a second (last) phase of the final boss fight. Keep in mind that this game *is* a 2D platforming game, so don't get confused, angry, discouraged or something else like that when you find yourself in space. It's okay.

												I bought this game without reading the description or reading reviews, because it was a 19 cent game that i could sell the cards of to get my money back. I like free things. As a result, i expected a trashy rouge-like or something, but i was pleasantly surprised by how it was actually a puzzle platformer.After reading the description, i have to agree that the game is like a 2d platformer version of portal in the way it uses the simple mechanic of teleporting with conserved momentum to complete interesting puzzles. The secrets were well hidden, and i got almost all of them until i exited the area to turn in the secrets accidentally, and couldnt get back because i activated a check point.The game took around 2 hours of gameplay to complete, and it was definitely worth 19 cents. To be honest, i would probably say its worth the 5 dollars too, since it was a hell of a good 2 hours.

Posted: April 24, 2015
												Readers, please keep in mind my reviews are a hundred percent subjective. I got this game gifted. I found the mechanics original but felt like seeing glitched textures very early when I tried it. It doesn't really seem to be normal white square in some places. I'm not a big fan of space adventures neither so much of shoot them all games but there are always chances for original exeptions to occur. Super metroid is an exeption in my tastes that I enjoy playing but I am not a fan at all of megaman or Metal Slug (from which I do enjoy at least the work on animation) though they are references for a certain amount of players. I wouldn't say it's a bad game but I'm not sure to find much entertainement in it to my concern unfortunately. It's important for this kind of game to show flawless design nowadays to be enjoyable. Although I give it a positive vote I do not enjoy it much yet. I'm not fan of minimalism or drab graphics (unless it would correspond to a choice that would help immersion like horror or a bit psychological or mental insanity) such as Risk of rain either unless there would be various worlds and that's why I will prefer games like Wings of Vi (very nice mix of difficulty a bit of gore and attractive design that is unsurprisely very successfully working on me) or Shantae or Fidding Teddy 2 where I appreciate the gameplay feeling and the atmosphere as well as the games it is inspired from. Any games that refer too much to realistic gun crafting and certain kinds of propaganda will highly increase chances to earn my dislike. Actually it's hard to define what makes old school like games attractive. But there are some ingredients that will most often help to make them enjoyable to replay more than once. It still remains very subjective as we are not always in the mood for the same things as well as we don't want to eat the same things everyday.

Posted: April 25, 2015
												SPOILERS BELOWThis is a pretty good game.  It's solid most of the way through.  There is one downside though: The final battle.  While most of the game focuses on puzzle platforming, the very final battle (at least I think it's the final battle) takes all the concepts of your adventure, and it...  Throws them in the trash.  While the first Grigori battle actually focused on your abilities with the teleport gun, the final battle doesn't.  It puts you in a little space battle of Grigori's ship vs. your ship.  No teleport gun, just blasters.  What makes the final battle even more terrible is that the boss seems to have every cheap attack available: Spread shot, homing missiles, and a beam that takes up a large portion of the screen.  It's even more frustrating when they are all used at once.  This battle is the only reason I haven't finished the game.  Is this a cheap review?  Yes.  Do I reccomend the game?  Overall, yes.  Do I recommend completing/beating the game?  No, I don't.

												Very short cute game. You can finish it in two hours. Graphics is not bad, but not incredible. Mechanics with jumping and teleporting make the game enjoyable. Story very shalow. Villain attacks your side, you have to go after him all alone. We don't know who your side is. Could be evil intergalactic empire populated by good ordinary people doing their jobs and the villain a freedom fighter who dares to defy the ruling empire. Of course he is used to being on the other side of the law so he looks like a pirate and its given him a bad rep. While you the hero are  a overzealous enforser of the said empire and you don't see how in the long run the empire is trampling on the lowest developed worlds while the prosperous worlds keep getting prosperous. Like I said shalow story, lost potential. Get the game at a discount and it doesn't matter its short. TL;DR Fun platformer game. Very short. Find it on a discount and buy it.

Posted: January 16, 2016
												In addition to all the other helpful reviews, I just want to add that Out There Somewhere is a well balanced game, not too hardcore, and the achievements are not painful but with a nice difficulty, if you're inclined to find all the powerups and stuff and go for 100% completion. Steam tells me it took me 9 hours, that was with several runs focusing on different achievements over the course of a few months and I enjoyed it. Going through the game to see the ending takes about 1 to 1,5 hours on an average person's first playthrough, maybe more if you get stuck, but there are guides on Steam and on youtube just in case. The quick run achievement has a 20 minutes time limit, and that leaves quite some room for errors. Still it feels like an achievement when you did it. :)The game never crashed and ran absolutely without performance problems on both my desktop (Win7 64bit) and an older singlecore laptop (Win7 32bit).

Posted: November 10, 2015
												Love it. It`s like Portal meets Metroid. You are a lone astronaut that crashed on an unknown planet where you have to survive by thinking you way through many platforming puzzles, armed only with your trusty teleport gun. The 2D perspective is key here and thanks to the clear 16 bit graphics these 2 create an excellent contrast and dimension for navigation puzzles. The soundtrack is amazing and keeps your blood flowing and your brain working. And your brain should keep working cause puzzles start easy and tend to get harder with each new screen passing. A must play for any fans of Portal or platformer puzzle games.

												It was pretty short (will probably take you about 45 min to 1 1/2 hours) which is why I would recommend putting it on your wishlist and waiting for it to go on sale (I got it for like $0.19). Great game, and if it had maybe 1 or 2 more hours of playtime I would say it was worth that full $5.00 price. (especially as you may have to go around the planet 2/3 times to get all the things)So, let's get to rating...Music: 8Good music, good sound effects, but nothing to write home about. Enjoyable.Gameplay: 7This game has been dealing well with the whole teleporting gun jig. Sometimes confusing, but in the end it was fun.Graphics: 8Good pixel art in there, though not the best one I have ever seen. Still, executed greatly.Replay value: 4There is no big reasons to keep going much further if not to get the 100% (for completionists). This one has been lacking in both duration -and- replay value. Good for players that are completionists, but nothing else.Total: 6,75A good title with interesting mechanics, but way too short.

Posted: March 30, 2016
Wow! What a game! I picked up the game on sale whilst drunk one night thinking that myself and a mate of mine would have a grand ole time with this cheeky, pixel art, puzzle-platformer game. And I was absolutely correct. We started playing with the idea of recording a lets play of the first 15 minutes and ended up shirking off our other recordings to keep playing for another hour and a half. Out There Somewhere is a perfect blend of challenging puzzles, a simple yet intriguing game mechanic, and a wonderful amount of tongue-in-cheek humor that all together keeps your mind actively engaged and your funny bone throughly tickled. MiniBoss did a wonderful job with Out There Somewhere, and we definitely hope they look to expand the game or create more games like it! Definitely pick up the game, it is absolutely worth the ridiculously low price tag. If you are interested in watching some gameplay here is the playthrough series we uploaded:

Posted: April 22, 2015
												Got this game for 21 cents. Best deal ever!This game is like metriod meets a portal gun. Except a little diffrent. When you shoot your gun when the "teleshot" as the game calls it, hits a wall, you instantley teleport there. Sounds simple, huh? Well just like portal, it gets crazy. Your teleshot preserves movement, so if you fire and then jump at the last second, you will jump at that other place you just teleported to. This can be used to jump, fire, then as soon as you hit the ground jump again to do basically a double jump. Theres also a bunch more mechanics as well, such as 3 diffrent beams, enemies, glass and wood, mirrors, and a bunch of other stuff. Also the achievments are pretty challanging (all but one) to get and can add hours of gameplay if you're into that. Overall, great mechanic, great soundtrack, love the metriod style, and challanging achievments. 9/10.Edit: theres a HUGE difficulty spike at the final boss, one misclick and you're screwed. Thought i'd mention that.

Posted: April 5, 2016
												Out There Somewhere is a game that feels like an homage to action platformer games like Cave Story and Metroid. It is on the short side of gameplay (about an hour or two), but I had fun the entire time and wanted more when it was over. It also has plenty of hard-to-reach areas with secrets that require some prior planning and well-timed actions once you have a feel for it on your first playthrough. It is a great game that brings back memories of early platformers with some new, creative elements of its own.I'd highly recommend this game to anyone with a couple of hours to spare and a desire to play something that's just plain fun.

Posted: June 12, 2015
												I got this amazing game for $0.18.This is the cheapest game I've ever bought, yet it's fun as hell!You earn trading cards too, so you practically earn your money back with cards you can sell if you buy this game on sale.96% off of a game that's amazing! I love it.Pros:• Hours of fun!• Amazingly cheap on Steam Summer Sale! $0.18 (or $0.19 depending where you live)!• You get trading cards which you can craft badges from, or sell them and earn more money than what you paid for the game.• Levels don't seem repetitive as there are new items and mechanics that appear every so often.Cons:• Awkward controls and you can't change them.• No settings in pause menu. You can only change settings on the main menu.• The game just shows a black screen infinitely when you launch it after you've bought it. You have to reboot/restart your computer in order to play the game for the first time.• The friendly aliens that you can talk to have no purpose except sometimes revealing information while most of the times they say something utterly useless.• Too difficult at some points. I just rage quit because I can't complete a level, lol.The cons aren't that bad. I bloody love this game!It's a crime for a game so good to be so cheap, even on Steam Summer Sale.

Posted: December 4, 2015
												Out There Somewhere is a nice puzzle platformer that genuinely feels like a mix of Cave Story and Portal. The game is pretty short - and it's fully possible to beat it within 20 minutes, which is one of the game's hardest challengest - but there's a bunch of things to collect that provides replay value. I got it for 17 cents when it was on sale, but it's honestly worth the money whatever the price.The music works with the setting and the graphics are done well and the gameplay is fair, but challenging. My only complaint is the shooting segments. While it's not hard to pick up on, it really clashes with the rest of the game's gameplay, and the fact that it's the final fight bizarre since your only experience with such segments is at the very beginning. But overall though, it's a great cheap game.

Posted: April 24, 2015
												I bought this game without reading the description or reading reviews, because it was a 19 cent game that i could sell the cards of to get my money back. I like free things. As a result, i expected a trashy rouge-like or something, but i was pleasantly surprised by how it was actually a puzzle platformer.After reading the description, i have to agree that the game is like a 2d platformer version of portal in the way it uses the simple mechanic of teleporting with conserved momentum to complete interesting puzzles. The secrets were well hidden, and i got almost all of them until i exited the area to turn in the secrets accidentally, and couldnt get back because i activated a check point.The game took around 2 hours of gameplay to complete, and it was definitely worth 19 cents. To be honest, i would probably say its worth the 5 dollars too, since it was a hell of a good 2 hours.

Posted: April 24, 2015
												Readers, please keep in mind my reviews are a hundred percent subjective. I got this game gifted. I found the mechanics original but felt like seeing glitched textures very early when I tried it. It doesn't really seem to be normal white square in some places. I'm not a big fan of space adventures neither so much of shoot them all games but there are always chances for original exeptions to occur. Super metroid is an exeption in my tastes that I enjoy playing but I am not a fan at all of megaman or Metal Slug (from which I do enjoy at least the work on animation) though they are references for a certain amount of players. I wouldn't say it's a bad game but I'm not sure to find much entertainement in it to my concern unfortunately. It's important for this kind of game to show flawless design nowadays to be enjoyable. Although I give it a positive vote I do not enjoy it much yet. I'm not fan of minimalism or drab graphics (unless it would correspond to a choice that would help immersion like horror or a bit psychological or mental insanity) such as Risk of rain either unless there would be various worlds and that's why I will prefer games like Wings of Vi (very nice mix of difficulty a bit of gore and attractive design that is unsurprisely very successfully working on me) or Shantae or Fidding Teddy 2 where I appreciate the gameplay feeling and the atmosphere as well as the games it is inspired from. Any games that refer too much to realistic gun crafting and certain kinds of propaganda will highly increase chances to earn my dislike. Actually it's hard to define what makes old school like games attractive. But there are some ingredients that will most often help to make them enjoyable to replay more than once. It still remains very subjective as we are not always in the mood for the same things as well as we don't want to eat the same things everyday.

Posted: December 11, 2015
												The reason I got this game was because the cards from it sold for more than the game itself cost when it was on sale... I expected absolute garbage from the game, yet found myself pleasantly surprised. There's actually a pretty good little game in here, worthy of attention even if it's not on sale oddly enough.The basic concept is you start out in a rather limited 2D space shooter. You get shot down, fall to the planet, and then have to collect parts to repair your ship and escape. The writing's mediocre at best, and the plot's hardly anything to write home about, but the gameplay really does shine surprisingly well.You have three buttons, other than left/right. These are jump, fire a gun when you find it eventually, and fire a teleporter gun. This sounds simple. It's not. They actually put pretty good effort into coming up with some creative puzzles that take a bit of thought to overcome with these few tools.Momentum's carried over, so if you fire a teleport shot, and it has enough time to travel, you can jump upward as it hits and keep going up from where you portal to. This is put to surprisingly good use with some really rather clever yet deceptively simple looking puzzles.Toss in a bit of exploration and some hidden goodies, advanced stuff and bonuses scattered around, and it's actually not a bad game at all.Yeah, the story sucks. Yeah, the dialgue is awful. Yeah, it's only about an hour long from start to finish. But you know what? It's CHEAP. And to be blunt, the gameplay itself is good enough to ignore all that and just sit down to a fun little puzzle game that vaguely has some ever so slight similarities to metroid.I can actually recommend this game at full price. It's actually worth it. Just don't expect it to have good writing is all. =P

Posted: June 27, 2016
												If you're tight on cash and looking for a relatively quick fix that's worth your time, look no further, this is the game to buy. The difficulty level is high enough that it'll take a good few runs before you're able to truly complete the game at 100% but it isn't so hard that you'll wanna uninstall immediately after not getting how to double jump (it takes a little practice). The cutscenes, as few as there may be, are fun to read and that might be primarily because the art is gorgeous in all of its pixel format glory and the story is executed well enough. Admittedly, I was a little reluctant to play the game given the price (I'm sure we've all made that lousy, cheap purchase and regretted it before) but this is not the case. The low price tag is a bonus. So, if you purchase this game and didn't enjoy it quite like you thought you would, I would like to know what spoilt it for you seeing as my experience with the game so far have exceeded my expectations but a long run. TL;DRThis is a great game and for its price, it's a steal.

Posted: March 2, 2016
												Let me open by saying this game is cheap, but is it worth the price tag?Yup.I recently played(and reviewed) a similar puzzle platformer, VVVVV or some nonsense, which I didn't find was to my liking.  As such I had some apprehension about Out There Somewhere.  I'll tell you that was some misplaced anxiety.  This game has a teleport mechnic that allows it to progress beyond simple muscle reflex puzzles and actually assess all the factors on a screen before proceeding with a solution.  After I completed the game, I felt satisfied.  I felt like I had accomplished some pretty interesting puzzle platforming, and I felt like I kind of wanted to play it through again.All that being said, this game isn't very long.  I don't know how much time I spent playing it, currently, but I think it was about an hour(Edit: 54 mins...)  which was actually perfect since I was on a flight and after I finished we were close to landing.  I see myself playing this again on my return trip and probably enjoying it just as much.One interesting thing I noticed in the options was the feature to turn on a timer, which seems an interesting little contraption to let you time your runs.  There's also a few areas I can think of where I may have been able to explore but they were early in the game before I really learned the capabilities of the teleporter gun.That's another bit that's interesting.  They don't throw new items at you through the game to make places accessible, with the exception of a gun near the beginning.  Anything you are able to accomplish late game with the teleporter you can do at the start... provided you grasp the concept fast enough.  The gun you obtain later is really only to destroy blocks and enemies, but it seemed to me (nearly) every screen could potentially be accomplished without killing a single enemy.The last bit I'll mention is that I played this game entirely on the Steam Controller, I've yet to find a platformer that doesn't work well with it, but I'll say playing a game on the plane was MUCH more comfortable with a controller in hand, rather than playing the part of a contortionist to access the keyboard wedged in front of me, though this is just commentary and doesn't affect my review of the game. Addition: OK, so since I was in an airplane and didn't pay for wifi, steam didn't register the time I'd played the game and wouldn't let me post a review with 0 minutes logged.  I started up a new game and can confirm in the 12 minutes of extra play time I found 3 screens I didn't even register existed on my first play through within the 'tutorial' section of the game.  So if you happen to be an achievement collector, or just like the game you can easily double that hour play time going through with a replay. Its worth the standard price(which is cheap as it is,) but if you find this game on sale, don't hesitate to nab it if you enjoy puzzle games or plaformers.  It's got some interesting mechanics.

Posted: December 6, 2016
												Definitely a good value for its price, especially if you get it on sale (which seems to happen frequently). Though definitely a short game, it ought to entertain for The few hours that you spend with it. The puzzles are nowhere near rage-inducingly difficult but very satisfying to solve, as they should be. The controls are responsive and reliable, so you'll suffer few to no cheap deaths. As a puzzle platformer, Out There Somewhere provides a strong enough gameplay framework that I would gladly play a much longer game in its style.But, as previously stated, it is a very short game. Playing at a natural pace, I attained my first completion in just over 40 minutes. Fortunately, there are several hidden screens and items, but even so, full completion shouldn't take more than a handful of hours.Oh, and just to put it out there, the boss in the intro cannot be beaten, as awesome as it would have been to beat the game without even starting it.

Posted: July 6, 2016
												Overall, this game is a fun experience! It's short, but at the price you can't really knock it for that. It's got a decent amount of replayability, especially if you want to find all the secrets and get all the achievments. It took me around 5 hours to get all the achivements, but anyone playing this just to play it will probably find themselves done in around an hour. The biggest thing I have against the game is that at one point it just switches from a platformer to a shmup, which wasn't a fun time for me, especially since it was a rather hard area. It's only one area, but in a game this small, that can be a huge downturn for me.If you're looking for a good hour or two of exploring around and platforming and puzzle solving, this game will get that itch from ya.

Posted: July 5, 2016
												Out There Somewhere is a 2D Adventure, Puzzle platformer developed and published by MiniBoss.The beginning starts like a retro space game and after that your plane crashes on planet Unknown and take on the journey to repair your plane. In every stage of the game there are puzzles to be solved.I bought it an year ago for about 0.15€ & since then you needed about 40-50 minutes to get the trading cards, I played, got them and uninstalled. But lately I've been struggling to find a good game that I haven't played (a lot) & this was one of the cheap games that was actually very good, so I gave it a try. After I completed the game, I can say that I am impressed from it.Pros:Retro graphicsPuzzles (every puzzle is different from the other)Teleport gun mechanicGood soundtrackCheapCons:Very short (about an hour average time)Combat (It's quite meh imo)TL; DRFan of retro, 2D, puzzle games? Then this game is for you and even in full price, the game is worth it!
